elements.title: Sir William Siemens
elements.contents: ... that when launched in 1896, the freighter Sir William Siemens (pictured) and her sister ships were the largest vessels on the Great Lakes?

elements.title: Elizabeth Parish
elements.contents: ... that Anna Maria Bowes escaped from her governess Elizabeth Parish by crawling over a plank to cross a narrow street?

elements.title: a West Virginia TV station
elements.contents: ... that the general manager of a West Virginia TV station called changing its network affiliation "the hardest decision I've ever had to make"?

elements.title: Akshata Murty
elements.contents: ... that Akshata Murty, the wife of British prime minister Rishi Sunak, reportedly has more personal wealth than King Charles III?

elements.title: ongoing Nakba
elements.contents: ... that the first public usage of the term "ongoing Nakba" is widely credited to Hanan Ashrawi, who referenced it in a speech at the 2001 World Conference against Racism?

elements.title: Michael S. Farbman
elements.contents: ... that Michael S. Farbman's reporting of the Russian Civil War in winter 1917–18 was described by The Observer as "one of the outstanding successes of the time in special correspondence"?

elements.title: Seamen's and Soldiers' False Characters Act 1906
elements.contents: ... that despite being in force for more than 100 years, no known prosecutions were made under the Seamen's and Soldiers' False Characters Act 1906?

elements.title: Bess Truman
elements.contents: ... that U.S. first lady Bess Truman was humiliated by a champagne bottle?
